creator: bugzilla@apache.org
text:
If the variable name's case was correct the variable is deleted, otherwise no 
variables is set.

Example (for NT):
<project name="test" default="main" basedir=".">
<target name="main">
  <exec dir="." executable="cmd" failonerror="yes">
    <arg value="/c"/>
    <arg value="set"/>
    <env key="Path" path="${java.library.path};path/to/bin"/>
    <env key="JAVA_HOME" path="${java.home}/.."/>
  </exec>
</target>
</project>

=============
both 'Path' and 'JAVA_HOME' variables are not present in the output. If path 
variable is written as 'PATH' - Path variable is not changed.

creator: bodewig@apache.org
text:
At least on Unix, environment variables are case sensitive, so there is nothing
much one can do.

I've run your example on Linux (using env as the executable), both Path and
JAVA_HOME have been set correctly - seems to be a Windows specific problem.
